text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with flank steak roll odd that's
right we're gonna butterfly stuff roll
and braised a cut of beef that's usually
never braised and maybe there's a reason
for that
but despite it's not awesomely beautiful
outside appearance the inside was
absolutely delicious and so I am deeming
this experiment and almost complete
success but anyway above and beyond
appearance and flavor I think this is
definitely a worthwhile technique to
learn and to get started you're going to
need two things one whole trimmed beef
flank steak and a thin sharp knife and
I'm sorry people that wanted to use dull
fat knives that's not going to work here
so we're going to start by cutting into
the side of this flank steak ideally
your knife is going right into the
center and the key here is to go nice
and slowly and as much as possible you
want to keep that knife perfectly flat
on the same plane as the cutting board
alright so you're not cutting down
you're not cutting up your cutting
perfectly straight across and by the way
I should have mentioned right off the
bat you have to butterfly it this way
the long ways are you see the direction
that those fibers in the meat are going
it's very crucial that once I roll out
is done and we're slicing it that we're
going to cross those fibers so it has to
be butterfly it exactly like this for
that to work but anyway we're going to
carefully continue to slice and
butterfly and there's going to be
mistakes so as usual do not shoot for
perfection so that's what might look
like post cutting I got a nice hole
there and this is split up there but it
doesn't matter you're going to see it's
going to work perfectly anyway because
of this next step so we'll kind of
overlap any tears like that we'll cover
this with plastic and we'll simply
flatten it all out with a meat pounder
and I love the style of pounder you see
me using here but if you don't have one
you could just use a small heavy pots
and as we problem we're not really
trying to make it much thinner we're
basically trying to even everything out
unless you're some kind of freaking
nature or a sushi chef there's just no
way you can butterfly that and have it
all the same thickness so we're gonna
give it a little pounding to even it all
out at that point we're going to peel
off the plastic and start to stuff this
with well stuff and we're going to go
ahead and start the inside with a nice
generous seasoning of kosher salt and
yes standard disclaimer kosher salt
looks like a ton on camera it's really
not it's a big piece of meat etc and so
forth next up we'll do some freshly
ground black pepper and then after the
pepper we're going to get a little bit
fruity and I'm going to scatter over
some currants love the
Curren those are also known as micro
raisins so we'll scatter some of those
around
maybe press them in a little bit so they
don't roll when we roll next up I'm
going to sprinkle over some plain
breadcrumbs all right now two too much
but I do want to cover the surface and
then next up we have some freshly
chopped Italian parsley nice generous
scattering of that then we'll bring the
heat with a little bit of red chili
flake and the gratuitous shaking of
cayenne oh yeah you're welcome and then
at this point I'm going to lay down some
very very thin strips of pancetta and by
the way you may have noticed I'm going
with a kind of an Italian theme here
kind of a take-off on the bridge all but
again to reiterate a roulade is not a
recipe it's a technique so you stuff
this with anything you want but anyway
after the pancetta we'll do a little bit
of grated Reggiano parmesan and these
ingredient amounts are going to be kind
of tough
it's basically enough to cover so it
might say a couple tablespoons on the
blog post but I have no idea how much it
really is and then before we roll this
up I'm going to give it another very
light dusting of breadcrumb just a
little extra something to soak up all
those amazing flavors and juices at that
point we're going to start at the bottom
and we're going to roll towards the
front and we're going to roll it up and
if you do need help ask that friend that
took you to the Phish concert they
probably have a feel for this so kind of
roll it firmly but not enough to squeeze
everything out of course tucking in the
edges if you can but anyway we're going
to roll that up nice and tight but not
too tight and then once it's perfectly
rolled and looking like that we're going
to unroll it and we're going to add some
pine nuts and now of course you're
asking why did you not add those pine
nuts when you did the rest of the
stuffing ingredients hey how dare you
question my methods but anyway we're
going to unroll it add some pine nuts
and roll it back up only this time we're
going to leave it rolled and we're going
to tie it so we're going to turn the
meat this way we're going to of course
have the seam on the bottom and all
we're going to do is take little pieces
of string and make individual ties this
is the easiest butcher tie ever and all
you need to do is twist that string
around four or five times before you
pull it tight and because of the
friction on that string it's going to
let you cinch it up beautifully
check it out and unless you're short on
string I do like to make a tie every
inch or two and then once that's all
tied up let's go ahead and season the
outside with a little salt and at that
point we're going to go over to the
stove and we're going to go ahead and
brown this in our braising pot so on
medium-high heat with a little bit of
olive oil go ahead and brown that on all
surfaces
and by the way if any rogue pine nuts
pop up get them out of the pot burned
nuts are one of those things that can
really cause an off flavor so if you see
a pine nut they could get too Brown pull
it out all right now the other stuff in
there would cause a problem and then
once that's brown we're going to go
ahead and add some braising liquid and
you can use pretty much anything here
you are the Big Chief of your beef
spleef but for me I threw in a splash of
white wine something cheap but drinkable
which of course that glaze the bottom
and in addition to the wine I'm also
going to add a fairly garlicky tomato
sauce some chicken broth and then just
enough water to kind of bring that up to
the top of the beef and because this
video is going to be too long already
I'll give you more info about that
braising liquid on the blog although I
will admit to put it in a bay leaf and
at that point how we're going to do is
wait for this to come up to a simmer and
as soon as it does we will turn our heat
down to the lowest setting we'll go
ahead and cover it and we will slowly
let this braise for about two-and-a-half
three hours or until its fork and or
knife tender so I'm going to check mine
here and it seemed perfect so I'm going
to go ahead and pull that out let it
rest on a plate at least ten minutes
before I slice it and yes of course
you're going to reserve that braising
liquid and reduce it and use it as a
sauce then we're gonna let that rest for
about ten minutes and then it's time to
slice and I was pretty excited at this
point because it smelled so good so I
cut in and while the outside was pretty
ugly I was hoping the inside would be
beautiful and it was check it out like I
said this was an experiment for me
because I had never butterflied and
braised a flank steak before so I cut
myself three nice slices I served that
with a couple side dishes I don't
remember I spooned over a little bit of
that braising liquid and that beef flank
steak roulade is done and ready for
examination so first up the taste test
it had a beautiful flavor but more
importantly had a great texture just
melt in your mouth
so taste was great internal appearance
was great the only thing I didn't like
was he outside because flank steak does
have those long very pronounced meat
fibers those kind of got a little frayed
on the outside and you can see the edges
have kind of a stringy not absolutely
beautiful look to them and while I
wasn't totally thrilled with how the
outside looked I think we can fix that
in the next version maybe we'll do some
kind of pancetta or prosciutto
exoskeleton
but anyway regardless of the specific
recipe still a worthwhile technique to
learn and I really do hope you give it a

comm for all the ingredient amounts
